title._: Principles for the management of credit risk

description._: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has issued a public consultation on a limited update of the Principles for the Management of Credit Risk ('Credit Risk Principles').

dc:title._: Principles for the management of credit risk

title._: Transparency and responsiveness of initial margin in centrally cleared markets - review and policy proposals

description._: This BCBS-CPMI-IOSCO report sets out ten final policy proposals which aim to increase the resilience of the centrally cleared market ecosystem in times of market stress.

dc:title._: Transparency and responsiveness of initial margin in centrally cleared markets - review and policy proposals

cb:simpleTitle._: Transparency and responsiveness of initial margin in centrally cleared markets - review and policy proposals

title._: Streamlining variation margin processes and initial margin responsiveness of margin models in non-centrally cleared markets

description._: This report by the BCBS and IOSCO sets out eight recommendations to participants in non-centrally cleared markets to encourage the widespread implementation of good market practices related to (i) variation margin processes; and (ii) the responsiveness of initial margin models.

dc:title._: Streamlining variation margin processes and initial margin responsiveness of margin models in non-centrally cleared markets

cb:simpleTitle._: Streamlining variation margin processes and initial margin responsiveness of margin models in non-centrally cleared markets

title._: Final guidelines for counterparty credit risk management

description._: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has issued guidelines for banks' counterparty credit risk (CCR) management. The guidelines include key practices critical to resolving long-standing industry weaknesses in CCR management, including the need to: (i) conduct comprehensive due diligence at both initial onboarding, as well as on an ongoing basis; (ii) develop a comprehensive credit risk mitigation strategy to effectively manage counterparty exposures; (iii) measure, control and limit CCR using a wide variety of complementary metrics; and (iv) build a strong CCR governance framework.

dc:title._: Final guidelines for counterparty credit risk management

cb:simpleTitle._: Final guidelines for counterparty credit risk management

title._: Regulatory Consistency Assessment Programme (RCAP): Assessment of Basel Committee's large exposures framework - Korea

description._: This report describes the Committee's assessment of the implementation of the Basel Committee's large exposures framework (LEX) in Korea. The Korean LEX regulations have been assessed as largely compliant.

dc:title._: Regulatory Consistency Assessment Programme (RCAP): Assessment of Basel Committee's large exposures framework - Korea

cb:simpleTitle._: Regulatory Consistency Assessment Programme (RCAP): Assessment of Basel Committee's large exposures framework - Korea

title._: Regulatory Consistency Assessment Programme (RCAP): Assessment of Basel Committee's Net Stable Funding Ratio standard - Korea

description._: This report describes the Committee's assessment of the implementation of the Basel Committee's Net Stable Funding Ratio (NSFR) standard in Korea. The Korean NSFR regulations have been assessed as compliant.

dc:title._: Regulatory Consistency Assessment Programme (RCAP): Assessment of Basel Committee's Net Stable Funding Ratio standard - Korea

cb:simpleTitle._: Regulatory Consistency Assessment Programme (RCAP): Assessment of Basel Committee's Net Stable Funding Ratio standard - Korea

title._: Finalisation of various technical amendments

description._: This document sets out various technical amendments to the Basel Framework. The amendments relate to: (i) the standardised approach to credit risk; and (ii) cryptoasset exposures.

title._: The 2023 banking turmoil and liquidity risk: a progress report

description._: This progress report to the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors provides an update on the Basel Committee's analytical work on the 2023 banking turmoil.

title._: Basel III monitoring report

description._: The report sets out the impact of the Basel III framework, including the December 2017 finalisation of the Basel III reforms and the January 2019 finalisation of the market risk framework.

dc:title._: Basel III monitoring report

cb:simpleTitle._: Basel III monitoring report

title._: Novel risks, mitigants and uncertainties with permissionless distributed ledger technologies

description._: Banks that transact on permissionless blockchains or similar distributed ledger technologies (DLTs) face various risks. This paper considers the risks related to operations and security, governance, legal, compliance (including money laundering/financing of terrorism) and settlement finality.

dc:title._: Novel risks, mitigants and uncertainties with permissionless distributed ledger technologies

cb:simpleTitle._: Novel risks, mitigants and uncertainties with permissionless distributed ledger technologies

title._: Principles for the sound management of third-party risk

description._: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has issued a consultative document proposing Principles for the sound management of third-party risk in the banking sector. The Principles address banks' increasing reliance on third-party service providers due to the ongoing digitalisation and rapid growth in financial technology. ...

title._: Various technical amendments and FAQs

description._: The set of interpretative issues addressed in this document relate to: (i) the standardised approach to credit risk; (ii) cryptoasset exposures; (iii) counterparty credit risk; (iv) the standardised approach to operational risk; (v) the simplified standardised, standardised and internal models approaches to market risk; and (vi) the net stable funding ratio.

dc:title._: Various technical amendments and FAQs

cb:simpleTitle._: Various technical amendments and FAQs

title._: Literature review on financial technology and competition for banking services

description._:
by Hein Bogaard, Sebastian Doerr, Nicole Jonker, Hua Kiefer, Onur Koltukcu, Calixto Lpez, Jos Renato Haas Ornelas, Ricky Rambharat, Sigrid Rhrs, Federica Teppa, Frans van Bruggen, Eric Vansteenberghe
The extent to which financial technology will shape the banking industry depends in part on the nature of competition for banking services that arises from innovation by incumbent banks and the entry of new players. This paper presents a review of the growing body of economic literature on financial technology and competition for banking services.

dc:title._: Literature review on financial technology and competition for banking services

cb:simpleTitle._: Literature review on financial technology and competition for banking services

cb:publication._: Bank for International Settlements: Working Papers

title._: Digitalisation of finance

description._: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has published a report which considers the implications of the ongoing digitalisation of finance on banks and supervision. This report builds on the Sound Practices: Implications of fintech developments for banks and bank supervisors published in 2018, and takes stock of recent developments in the digitalisation of finance.

dc:title._: Digitalisation of finance

cb:simpleTitle._: Digitalisation of finance

title._: Guidelines for counterparty credit risk management

description._: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has issued a consultation on guidelines for counterparty credit risk management. The proposed guidelines include key practices critical to resolving long-standing industry weaknesses in counterparty credit risk management, including the need to: (i) conduct comprehensive due diligence at both initial onboarding, as well as on an ongoing basis; (ii) develop a comprehensive credit risk mitigation strategy to effectively manage counterparty exposures; (iii) measure, control and limit CCR using a wide variety of complementary metrics; and (iv) build a strong CCR governance framework.

dc:title._: Guidelines for counterparty credit risk management

title._: Core Principles for effective banking supervision

description._: This publication sets out the revised Core Principles for effective banking supervision ("Core Principles"). The revised Core Principles were endorsed by banking supervisors at the 23rd International Conference of Banking Supervisors held in Basel, Switzerland, on 24-25 April 2024.

dc:title._: Core Principles for effective banking supervision

cb:simpleTitle._: Core Principles for effective banking supervision

title._: The role of climate scenario analysis in strengthening the management and supervision of climate-related financial risks

description._: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has issued a discussion paper on how climate scenario analysis (CSA) can be practically used to help strengthen the management and supervision of climate-related financial risks.

dc:title._: The role of climate scenario analysis in strengthening the management and supervision of climate-related financial risks

cb:simpleTitle._: The role of climate scenario analysis in strengthening the management and supervision of climate-related financial risks

title._: Banks' window-dressing of the G-SIB framework: causal evidence from a quantitative impact study

description._: Exploiting a novel and uniquely extensive bank-level dataset, this study employs a difference-in-differences empirical strategy to test whether the response of banks to the G-SIB framework – a key component of the Basel III macroprudential reforms – directly contributes to window-dressing behaviour.

dc:title._: Banks' window-dressing of the G-SIB framework: causal evidence from a quantitative impact study

cb:simpleTitle._: Banks' window-dressing of the G-SIB framework: causal evidence from a quantitative impact study

cb:publication._: Bank for International Settlements: Working Papers

title._: G-SIB denominators and scores dynamics: a ten-year assessment

description._: This paper examines the global systemically important bank (G-SIB) framework ten years after its introduction, covering three complementary perspectives: the evolution of the G-SIB denominators, the relative evolution of scores of G-SIBs and non-G-SIBs, and the adjustments in the balance sheets of G-SIBs.

dc:title._: G-SIB denominators and scores dynamics: a ten-year assessment

cb:simpleTitle._: G-SIB denominators and scores dynamics: a ten-year assessment

cb:publication._: Bank for International Settlements: Working Papers

title._: Global systemically important banks - revised assessment framework

description._: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision issued today a consultation on revisions to the global systemically important banks (G-SIB) assessment framework aimed at mitigating "window-dressing" behaviour by some banks in the context of the G-SIB framework.

dc:title._: Global systemically important banks - revised assessment framework
